channel.title: Hidden Jar Files
channel.description: This is for a friend, when making an executable jar file, what option or w/e makes them hidden so you can't extract the .jar?

item.title: Hidden Jar Files
item.dc:creator: @ada ada
item.description:
@ada wrote:

[quote=“semaphore, post:11, topic:10158”]If it’s obfuscation you want, you chose the wrong language to develop with. You should be learning c and asm.

For the safest product, develop a subscription based system where the service is remote and no sensitive code resides on the client. The client is ‘dumb’ and it wouldn’t particularly matter much how ‘hacked’ the client was, if the token is invalid, no service is rendered.

If you want a very good example of client-side protection, take a look at the recent-ish versions of Mousepad’s maphack for d2. It was brilliant and incredibly effective.

The bane of java is that it is trivial to ‘hack’. Even know-it-all (know-nothing) kids trying to hack a third or fourth class game have some success.[/quote]

Yes, but this person probably knows Java the best or is doing something only Java can do.

Read full topic

item.title: Hidden Jar Files
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

If it’s obfuscation you want, you chose the wrong language to develop with. You should be learning c and asm.

For the safest product, develop a subscription based system where the service is remote and no sensitive code resides on the client. The client is ‘dumb’ and it wouldn’t particularly matter much how ‘hacked’ the client was, if the token is invalid, no service is rendered.

If you want a very good example of client-side protection, take a look at the recent-ish versions of Mousepad’s maphack for d2. It was brilliant and incredibly effective.

The bane of java is that it is trivial to ‘hack’. Even know-it-all (know-nothing) kids trying to hack a third or fourth class game have some success.

Read full topic

item.title: Hidden Jar Files
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

[quote=“RLN, post:8, topic:10158”][quote author=Krichevskoy link=topic=14773.msg170762#msg170762 date=1156095183]

[quote author=RLN link=topic=14773.msg168126#msg168126 date=1156009957]

http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,12011.0.html
or
Make your own jar encrypter. Its not that hard - if he has any code worth hiding he’ll be able to make this.

But you always have to give straight classes to the ClassLoader. A little more than zero additional security, but only just.
[/quote]That would require modifying rt.jar or cracking the encryption, both pretty annoying to do.

Not at all, it would just require finding where your custom classloader calls defineClass.
[/quote]It would still be annoying if you did it via bytecode too, especially if you used the class’ file length as a key[/quote]

I don’t see how the encryption you use matters at all - it’s all gone by the time you reach the point I’m talking about. It’s an implementation attack. You still have to give a very standard data array to the VM classloader. Yes, encryption would prevent someone who just comes across your classes in the absence of the rest of the program from using them, but how often would that happen?

ada:

Why not just obfuscate the class files. If a person tries to decompile the files they wont get much from it

That’s really the best you can do with Java, though this entire community is proof that there are ways around it (honestly, what other major Java programs are there?)

Read full topic

item.title: Hidden Jar Files
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

There’s no way to do it - a jar file is simply a zip file. There are such applications out there that can package the jar into a binary executable (exe), either the executable will be just be an archive as well or it will have to extract the classes to the system temporary directory to run. There’s no way to totally hide the classes.

Read full topic
